dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:alternative: DIALOGUES 2: Dialogues lus, conçus pour une étude phonétique portant sur l'influence de l'attitude du locuteur sur la réalisation de deux particules finales du vietnamien de Hanoi
ĐỐI THOẠI 2: Đối thoại được thiết kế cho việc nghiên cứu sự biến đổi đặc tính âm học của hai trợ từ tình thái cuối câu trong Tiếng Việt, thể hiện theo các thái độ khác nhau (Hà Nội)
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: Information on FORM: This file (electroglottographic signal for speaker M5) is one of the three channels that constitute the entire resource. The present audio file is the electroglottographic signal collected for speaker M5. In addition to this file, there exist two other data files: audio signal for speaker M5; and audio signal for speaker M4. Finally, a fourth file was created for ease of consultation by mixing the two audio channels into a (single-channel) WAV file. These files were also deposited in the archive. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
International Research Institute MICA, HUST – CNRS/UMI-2954 – Grenoble INP, Hanoi University of Science and Technology
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: Vietnam, Hanoi
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: vie
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: DIALOGUES 2: Read dialogues designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. This file is one of 3 original files: it contains the audio for speaker M5 (see description).

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:alternative: ĐỐI THOẠI 1: Đối thoại được thiết kế cho việc nghiên cứu sự biến đổi đặc tính âm học của hai trợ từ tình thái cuối câu trong Tiếng Việt, thể hiện theo các thái độ khác nhau (Hà Nội)
DIALOGUES 1: Dialogues lus, conçus pour une étude phonétique portant sur l'influence de l'attitude du locuteur sur la réalisation de deux particules finales du vietnamien de Hanoi
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: Information on FORM: This document (audio+EGG) is an edited version of the document Dialogues1, retaining only the sentences that were relevant for a study of sentence-final particles conducted in 2013. During data processing, the data sets for speakers M4 and M5 were edited to retain only the passages relevant for analysis. These documents are less complete than the set presented with XML annotation/transcription, and they are not time-aligned between the two speakers; they are nonetheless made available, in case they should be of interest, for instance to someone who wished to replicate our measurements over the data for all four speakers. In the version made available here, each file is annotated with the SoundForge software. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
International Research Institute MICA, HUST – CNRS/UMI-2954 – Grenoble INP, Hanoi University of Science and Technology
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: Vietnam, Hanoi
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: vie
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: DIALOGUES 1: Read dialogues designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. This file is an EDITED file, not an original (see description).

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: CN

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: This is a description of trade in the old times (about the middle of the 20th century), which was provided, in conversational mode, after the recording of the story « Trader and his son ». The speaker provides some explanations about how hemp clothes, one of the commodities produced in Yongning, used to be produced and sold.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:alternative: DIALOGUES 2: Dialogues lus, conçus pour une étude phonétique portant sur l'influence de l'attitude du locuteur sur la réalisation de deux particules finales du vietnamien de Hanoi
ĐỐI THOẠI 2: Đối thoại được thiết kế cho việc nghiên cứu sự biến đổi đặc tính âm học của hai trợ từ tình thái cuối câu trong Tiếng Việt, thể hiện theo các thái độ khác nhau (Hà Nội)
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: Information on FORM: This document (audio+EGG) is an edited version of the document Dialogues2, retaining only the sentences that were relevant for a study of sentence-final particles conducted in 2013. During data processing, the data sets for speakers M4 and M5 were edited to retain only the passages relevant for analysis. These documents are less complete than the set presented with XML annotation/transcription, and they are not time-aligned between the two speakers; they are nonetheless made available, in case they should be of interest, for instance to someone who wished to replicate our measurements over the data for all four speakers. In the version made available here, each file is annotated with the SoundForge software. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: Vietnam, Hanoi
VN
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: vie
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: DIALOGUES 2: Read dialogues designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. This file is an EDITED file, not an original (see description).

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher. The items are not lexical: the reading task is based on the writing system: Naxi Pinyin 纳西拼音 (in Naxi: Naqxi Piyi).
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale

DIALOGUES 1: Dialogues lus, conçus pour une étude phonétique portant sur l'influence de l'attitude du locuteur sur la réalisation de deux particules finales du vietnamien de Hanoi
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: Information on FORM: This file (electroglottographic signal for speaker M4) is one of the three channels that constitute the entire resource. The present file is the electroglottographic signal collected for speaker M4. In addition to this file, there exist two other data files: audio signal for speaker M4; and audio signal for speaker M5. Finally, a fourth file was created for ease of consultation by mixing the two audio channels into a (single-channel) WAV file. These files were also deposited in the archive. Information on CONTENTS: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
International Research Institute MICA, HUST – CNRS/UMI-2954 – Grenoble INP, Hanoi University of Science and Technology
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: Vietnam, Hanoi
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: vie
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: DIALOGUES 1: Read dialogues designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. This file is one of 3 original files: it contains the audio for speaker M4 (see description).

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: SmoothTones: The six tones of sonorant-ending syllables of Hanoi Vietnamese, on the syllables /a/ and /ɗa/. Speaker M7
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
International Research Institute MICA, HUST – CNRS/UMI-2954 – Grenoble INP, Hanoi University of Science and Technology

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: vie
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: SmoothTones: The six tones of sonorant-ending syllables of Hanoi Vietnamese, on the syllables /a/ and /ɗa/. Speaker M7

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit. The documents from M6 and M7 are not complete dialogues: speakers M6 and M7 are colleagues at the MICA institute. They managed the task themselves: the interviewer served as dialogue partner when requested; otherwise the speakers only read the target sentences, in the manner they deemed most appropriate to convey the intended attitude. Each file is annotated with the SoundForge software.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
Multimédia, Informations, Communication et Applications
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: Vietnam, Hanoi
VN
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: vie
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: SimulatedDialogues: materials for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese (see description). Speaker M7.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher. The items are not lexical: the reading task is based on the writing system: Naxi Pinyin 纳西拼音 (in Naxi: Naqxi Piyi).

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: A narrative about how a trader taught his son to manage trade wisely. To his son’s surprise, the father asked him to collect stories along the way, as gifts to the father, instead of buying presents. The father’s message was that traders must avoid being left without sufficient stocks of food when they come back, and therefore should not spend their money hastily on pretty objects on sale at distant places.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: 中国云南省丽江市宁蒗县永宁乡平静村
Chine, province du Yunnan, comté de Yongning, village de ə˧lɑ˧-ʁwɤ˧
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: nru
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: Trader and his son: how a trader taught his son how to handle the ups and downs of commerce

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching the consultant writing calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: This is a set of read dialogues. They were designed for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese. Further details are provided in a PDF document associated to this deposit. The documents from M6 and M7 are not complete dialogues: speakers M6 and M7 are colleagues at the MICA institute. They managed the task themselves: the interviewer served as dialogue partner when requested; otherwise the speakers only read the target sentences, in the manner they deemed most appropriate to convey the intended attitude. Each file is annotated with the SoundForge software.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: SimulatedDialogues: materials for phonetic research into the influence of speaker attitude on the realization of two sentence-final particles in Hanoi Vietnamese (see description). Speaker M6.

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: The consultant was shown the target items in writing, as part of a randomized list on paper. The imagined context was that people are watching a TV programme about calligraphy. The target words were recorded under two reading conditions: the context for the first reading, referred to below as CAREFUL, is that a child asks which character is being written, and the consultant provides the answer. Under the second condition, referred to as IMPATIENT, the child is naughty, asking for the umpteenth time without paying attention to answers; the consultant says the answer again, but in a way that will clarify to the child that (s)he is being rude and should not speak up again. A final affirmative particle /mɤ̀/, reduplicated to /mɤ̌~mɤ̀/ for emphasis, is added to the carrier sentence to facilitate the rendering of this attitude. The reason for asking consultants to imagine a TV show, rather than a live performance, is so that they will not feel called upon to whisper the answer in order not to disturb the (fictitious) calligrapher. The items are not lexical: the reading task is based on the writing system: Naxi Pinyin 纳西拼音 (in Naxi: Naqxi Piyi).
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:spatial: CN

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:creator: Michaud, Alexis
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:description: This recording narrates how a young man who studied Tibetan Buddhism in Lhasa came back empty-handed, without a gift for his mother ; on the way, he plucked a tooth from a dead horse and told his mother it was a god’s tooth. His mother marvelled at this extraordinary gift and prayed three times a day to the tooth. Her faith was so intense that the tooth, originally a fake relic, eventually started to blaze and sparkle.
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:publisher: Laboratoire de langues et civilisations à tradition orale

dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:subject: nru
dcterms:dcterms.dcterms:title: Tooth: how a fake relic became a real one
